questions.question: What are the lethal doses (IDLH) for NO and CO as mentioned in the text?
questions.answer: NO has an IDLH of 100 ppm and CO has an IDLH of 1200 ppm.

questions.question: Based on the synthesis conditions provided, which MOFs were prepared for CO adsorption studies?
questions.answer: Mg2(DOBDC) and Co2(DOBDC) MOFs were prepared for CO adsorption studies.

questions.question: What was the unique feature of the Co2(DOBDC) MOF when exposed to NO gas as observed through single-crystal X-ray diffraction?
questions.answer: The unique feature was the direct coordination of NO molecules to the cobalt centers of the Co2(DOBDC) framework.

questions.question: How does the presence of water affect the NO@Co2(DOBDC) framework during the aromatization reaction of EDDD?
questions.answer: The presence of water vapor completes the release of coordinated NO molecules from the framework through water-to-nitric oxide exchange, facilitating the aromatization reaction.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the aminocarbonylation reaction using CO@Mg2(DOBDC) compared to using direct CO gas?
questions.answer: The yield of the aminocarbonylation reaction using CO@Mg2(DOBDC) (56%) was practically identical to the one obtained using direct CO gas (58%).

questions.question: Is it true that the Co2(DOBDC) framework can be recycled without sacrificing product yield after being used as a CO delivery vessel?
questions.answer: True, the Co2(DOBDC) framework can be recycled without sacrificing product yield after being used as a CO delivery vessel.

questions.question: Does the addition of air and water significantly improve the yield of the aromatization reaction using NO@Co2(DOBDC)?
questions.answer: True, the addition of air and water significantly improves the yield of the aromatization reaction using NO@Co2(DOBDC).

questions.question: What was the role of Rh3(BTC)2 in the carbonylative Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction?
questions.answer: Rh3(BTC)2 was used for CO delivery and acted as a catalyst in the absence of PdCl2, leading to product formation.

questions.question: What was the effect of using CO@Co2(DOBDC) in the aminocarbonylation reaction compared to using CO@Mg2(DOBDC)?
questions.answer: Using CO@Co2(DOBDC) resulted in a higher yield (67%) in the aminocarbonylation reaction compared to using CO@Mg2(DOBDC).

questions.question: Can CO@Rh3(BTC)2 be used in the carbonylative Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction without an additional catalyst?
questions.answer: True, CO@Rh3(BTC)2 can be used in the carbonylative Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction without an additional catalyst.

questions.question: Was the structural integrity of Mg2(DOBDC) preserved after its use in the aminocarbonylation reaction?
questions.answer: True, the structural integrity of Mg2(DOBDC) was preserved after its use in the aminocarbonylation reaction.

questions.question: What was the yield of the carbonylative Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction using CO@Mg2(DOBDC)?
questions.answer: The yield of the carbonylative Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction using CO@Mg2(DOBDC) was 49%.

questions.question: Is it true that the CO binding energy was estimated to be higher for Rh3(BTC)2 compared to M2(DOBDC) MOFs?
questions.answer: True, the CO binding energy was estimated to be higher for Rh3(BTC)2 compared to M2(DOBDC) MOFs.

questions.question: What was the effect of Pd nanoparticle impregnation within the Co2(DOBDC) framework?
questions.answer: Pd nanoparticle impregnation within the Co2(DOBDC) framework allowed it to serve as both a catalyst and a CO carrier in the carbonylative Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction.

questions.question: Did the use of CO@Cu2.38Rh0.62(BTC)2 result in product formation in the carbonylative Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction without PdCl2?
questions.answer: False, the use of CO@Cu2.38Rh0.62(BTC)2 did not result in product formation in the absence of PdCl2.

questions.question: What was the role of oxygen in the aromatization reaction using NO@Co2(DOBDC)?
questions.answer: Oxygen played a critical role in accelerating the aromatization reaction and significantly increased the yield when used alongside NO@Co2(DOBDC).

questions.question: Is it true that the structural integrity of Co2(DOBDC) was preserved after exposure to NO gas?
questions.answer: True, the structural integrity of Co2(DOBDC) was preserved after exposure to NO gas.

questions.question: What was the yield of the aromatization reaction of EDDD using NO@Co2(DOBDC) with the addition of water and air?
questions.answer: The yield of the aromatization reaction of EDDD using NO@Co2(DOBDC) with the addition of water and air was 88%.

questions.question: How did the presence of water vapor affect the NO@Co2(DOBDC) sample during the aromatization reaction?
questions.answer: The presence of water vapor facilitated the release of NO from the NO@Co2(DOBDC) sample, as indicated by the color change from black to orange.

questions.question: Can the Co2(DOBDC) framework be used multiple times for CO delivery in organic reactions without loss of crystallinity?
questions.answer: True, the Co2(DOBDC) framework can be used multiple times for CO delivery in organic reactions without loss of crystallinity.
